title: Thailand Tiger Temple to reopen under different name after abuse was discovered | Metro News
text:
Nicole Morley for Metro.co.uk Friday 24 Feb 2017 8:33 am The Tiger Temple was closed last year amid allegations of abuse (Picture: World Animal Protection) 
A notorious tiger farm linked to trafficking and animal cruelty is reopening under another name. 
Thailand’s infamous Tiger Temple was closed down last year amid allegations of illegal breeding and trafficking of big cats. 
In May 2016, more than 500 officers from Thailand’s Department of National Parks, Wildlife and Plant Conservation (DNP) raided the tourist attraction uncovering dead cubs in freezers alongside tiger skins, amulets and tiger teeth trinkets. Man sends girlfriend bouquet of ‘flowers’ made of £1,100 in bank notes 
More than 40 frozen tiger cubs were found, though it is not exactly clear how the carcasses would have been used. 
International animal welfare charity, World Animal Protection claim that Thailand’s controversial Tiger Temple Co. Ltd. is planning to re-open under the new name, Golden Tiger (Thailand) Co. Ltd. (Picture: World Animal Protection) To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video Last year 40 dead tiger cubs were discovered at a freezer in the temple (Picture: World Animal Protection) 
The Golden Tiger (Thailand) Co. Ltd. is currently constructing a new venue in Kanchanaburi, west Thailand, and have already been issued a provisional license by the DNP. 
Dr. Jan Schmidt-Burbach, senior wildlife advisor at World Animal Protection said: ‘Tiger farms have nothing to do with conservation – they just bring extreme suffering to these wild animals whilst living in appalling conditions. Woman stops brutal gang attack by using her car as a weapon 
‘These venues need to be stopped in their tracks because they clearly have links to the dark side of wildlife trafficking rings.’ 
Adding that tourists can play their part in preventing animal cruelty in Thailand, Dr Schmidt-Burbach added: ‘Tourists need to be aware that their once in a lifetime opportunity to get up close to a tiger causes a lifetime of suffering. 
‘A selfie with a tiger is cruel, so don’t do it.’ The international animal charity have warned tourists not to take pictures with tigers (Picture: World Animal Protection) 
Last year World Animal Protection released a study on tigers used for entertainment in Thailand which documented a 33% increase in the number of tigers at tourism facilities over a five-year period. Thailand's notorious Tiger Temple 
The main welfare concerns witnessed by the investigators at these tourist venues include: Tiger cubs cruelly separated from their mothers, two to three weeks after they are born Young cubs used as photo props with tourists; constantly viewed and mishandled hundreds of times a day, which can lead to stress and injury Tigers being punished to stop aggressive unwanted behavior. One staff member told our researchers that starvation is used to punish the tigers when they make a ‘mistake’ Most tigers were housed in small concrete cages or barren enclosures with limited access to fresh water. 50% of the tigers we observed were in cages with less that 20sqm per animal, a far cry from the 16-32km they would roam in a single night in the wild More than one in ten (12%) of the tigers we observed showed behavioral problems; such as repetitive pacing and biting their tales. These behaviors most commonly occur when animals feel they can’t cope with stressful environments or situations. More
